Ethmoidal polyps
Antrochoanal polyp
Allergic fungal sinusitis
Chronic rhinosinusitis
questions.solution:
• Antrochoanal polyp has infection as major cause
  • Intranasal topical Steroids are given after FESS for Allergic conditions- Ethmoidal polyps, Allergic fungal sinusitis & Chronic rhinosinusitis

questions.text: A 30 year old, non lactating nulliparous woman presents with milk discharge from bilateral breasts. Her serum prolactin levels are 220 ng/mL. Which of the following drugs is the next best step in her pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
Bromocriptine and cabergoline both are dopamine agonist drugs used in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia.

Cabergoline is now the DOC for hyperprolactinemia.

Bromocriptine is associated with giddiness, dizziness, postural hypotension, and, rarely, hallucinations. Besides, it needs to be taken daily.

Cabergoline has hardly any side effects (occasional headaches can happen), and it is to be taken once a week. Therefore, it is preferred over bromocriptine.

questions.text: A 45 years old man is admitted in ICU with a chief complaint of breathlessness, fever and dry cough for 3 days. Patient recently travelled to China. Nasal and throat swab were taken and results are awaited. Meanwhile patient undergone a chest CT. Which of the following CT Chest findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Given the clinical history and recent travelling history, most likely diagnosis is COVID-19 infection. CT chest findings are:

The primary findings on CT in adults have been reported as:

  • ground glass opacities (GGO): bilateral, subpleural, peripheral
  • crazy paving appearance (GGOs and inter-/intra-lobular septal thickening)
  • air space consolidation
  • bronchovascular thickening
  • traction bronchiectasis

The ground-glass and/or consolidative opacities are usually bilateral, peripheral, and basal in distribution.

questions.text: Anaemia is discovered in a 66-year-old lady. She had a barium enema as part of her evaluation, which revealed a mass lesion in the right side of her large intestine. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution: A mass in the right side of the large intestine and anaemia makes caecal carcinoma the likely diagnosis from the given options. Usually the patient presents with unexplained pain in the right iliac fossawith or without general symptoms such as anaemia, malaise and weakness. However it is important to note that abdominal pain often develops latein the disease. Cancers arising on the right side of the large intestine (ascending colon and caecum) tend to be exophytic. For that reason, it very rarely causes obstruction of faeces, and presents with symptoms such as anaemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady appears with 3 hours of acute intermittent right-sided stomach discomfort radiating to the groin. She has been writhing in pain for the past hour and has vomited twice. The WBC count is 14 x 109/L, and the CRP level is 83 mg/l. A urine HCG test came back negative. What is the MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF HER ABDOMINAL DISCOMFORT?
questions.solution:
The intermittent right sided abdominal pain radiating to the groin indicates a stone at the lower ureter.

Urinary tract stones

Clinical features

  • ‘Ureteric/renal colic’. Severe, intermittent, stabbing pain radiating from loin to groin.
  • Microscopic or, rarely, frank haematuria.
  • Systemic symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, pyrexia.
  • Loin or renal angle tenderness due to infection or inflammation.
  • Iliac fossa tenderness if the calculus has passed into the distal ureter.

Investigations

  • Raised WCC and CRP suggest superadded infection (should be confirmed by MSU);
  • Stones often visible on plain abdominal X-ray (‘kidneys/ureters/bladder’ (KUB)).
  • Non-contrast spiral CT is the gold standard for locating stones and assessing evidence of complications.
  • VU will locate stones and show any proximal obstruction.
  • Renal ultrasound scan for hydronephrosis

questions.text: A 50 year old post - menopausal female presents with patches of brownish discoloration on her nose, cheeks and forehead. A diagnosis of melasma is made. Which is an appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Melasma

  • Etiology
    • Hormonal
    • Pregnancy
    • OCP intake
    • Hormonal replacement
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Sun exposure
    • Excessive UVB exposure
  • C/F: Types of melasma
    1. Centrofacial - M/Ctype
    • Centre part of face is involved (nose, cheek, forehead)
    • Brownish discoloration over nose, cheek forehead

2. Mandibular-Brownish discoloration overmandibular area
3. Maxillary

Note:- Melasma-due to excessive melanogenesis
↓
Excessive melanin
↓
lesions are brown

  • Diagnosis: Clinical
  • Treatment:-Tyrosinase inhibitors / depigmentary agents (Tyrosinase is a Rate limiting enzyme for Melanogenesis)
  • E.g.: Topical
    1. Hydroquinone
    2. Azelaic acid
    3. Kojic acid
    4. Arbutin
  • Advise: Sun Protection-physical-cover the face Chemical-Sun screens

questions.text: Choose the correct sequence of steps of labor?

choices.text: Engagement – descent – flexion – external rotation – delivery by extension
Engagement – descent – flexion – internal rotation – delivery by extension
Engagement – flexion – descent – internal rotation – delivery by flexion
Engagement – flexion – descent – external rotation – delivery by flexion

questions.solution:
Cardinal movements of labor:-


Engagement
↓
Descent
↓
Flexion
↓
Internal rotation
↓
Extension
↓
External rotation
↓
Expulsion of Fetus

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman believes she is in love with a famous politician who sends her flowers every day. When he speaks openly on television, she claims he throws indications that he loves her. This lady has had no touch with the well-known politician. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Erotomaniac stalkers have the delusional belief that another person, usually of highersocial status, is secretly in love with them. The sufferer may also believe that thesubject of their delusion secretly communicates their love through seeminglyinnocuous acts, or if they are a public figure through clues in the media. The object ofthe delusion usually has little or no contact with the sufferer, who often believes theobject initiated the fictional relationship. Erotomaniac delusions are typically foundas the primary symptom of a delusional disorder, and in schizophrenia or mania.

Definitions of other options given in this question

Pyromania → an impulse control disorder in which individuals repeatedly fail to resistimpulses to deliberately start fires, in order to relieve tension or for instantgratification.

Rejected stalker → Pursues a victim in order to reverse, correct, or avengerejection (e.g. divorce, separation, termination of relationship).

Trichotillomania → an impulse disorder characterized by the compulsive urge to pullout one's hair, leading to noticeable hair loss and balding.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years, P3L3A1 presents with secondary amenorrhea for the past 6 months since she underwent a D and C (Dilatation and curettage). There is no withdrawal bleeding even after combined pill. Hysteroscopy done reveals intrauterine adhesions. The risk of such presentation is maximum if the D and C was done for which of the following indications?
questions.solution:
• Uterine synechiae (Asherman syndrome) are caused by destruction of large areas of endometrium by curettage.
  • In postpartum hemorrhage, a greater area of uterine wall is curetted, since the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier.
  • Also, in PPH , the uterus is much more vascular and hence any injury is healed more vigorously resulting in fibrosis
  • Hence, the risk of Asherman is greatest if D&C is done in postpartum period.

questions.text: Which of these is NOT a radioresistant bone tumor?
questions.solution:
Radio resistant Bone Tumors
  • Mneumonic – CMO
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma
  • osteosarcoma

Ewing Sarcoma is a highly radio-sensitive tumor, melts quickly but recurs. In most cases, distant metastasis has occurred by the time diagnosis is made.

questions.text: A 52-year-old alcoholic arrives at the Emergency Department with severe epigastric and back pain. There are moments when he is pain-free and other times when he is in discomfort. He also complains of loose, colourless, and foul-smelling faeces. He has lost weight in recent months, which he relates to his fear of eating, which he owes to the fact that his pains often intensify after eating. He exhibits epigastric soreness on examination. An x-ray of the abdomen revealed diffuse calcifications in the abdominal cavity. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?

choices.text: Carcinoma of the head of pancreas

questions.solution:
Chronic pancreatitis often presents with abdominal pain. Classically, the pain is located at the epigastrium and radiates to the back. The pain is worse after eating leading to a dislike of eating with consequent weight loss. The second most predominant feature is malabsorption which is represented here by steatorrhoea. Malabsorption again contributes to weight loss.

Alcohol is one of the significant risk factors for chronic pancreatitis but it is not a good hint to pick chronic pancreatitis as the answer based on an alcohol history as alcohol also contributes to acute pancreatitis, gastro-oesophageal reflux, oesophagitis and indirectly to pancreatic cancer.

One might consider “Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas” as the answer given the similar symptoms of weight loss, epigastric pain and history of alcohol. In reality, it is difficult to differentiate the two hence the importance of imaging modalities such as ultrasounds and CT scans.

In chronic pancreatitis, plain abdominal films of pancreas can show diffuse calcifications which indicate significant damage to the pancreas. X-rays of the abdomen are not one of the main imaging modalities of the pancreas, and it is usually done for other reasons such as to exclude bowel perforation in emergency. Again to stress that ultrasound and CT scans would be better imaging modalities for pancreatic diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics causes methemoglobinemia:-
questions.solution:
Methaemoglobinaemia is caused by prilocaine,benzocaine, and lidocaine

  • Prilocaineis the local anesthetic that is metabolizedtoo-toluidine in liver, which oxidizes hemoglobin to methemoglobin producing methemoglobinemia.
  • This is usually significant with doses of prilocaine as large as 600mg.
  • Benzocaine used in topical local anesthetic sprays can also cause dangerous Methemoglobinemia.
  • Treatment of medically important methemoglobinemia includes intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min, total dose should not exceed 7-8 mg/kg). Methylene blue acts by reducing methemoglobin (Fe 3+ ) to hemoglobin (Fe 2+ ). Normally methemoglobin is <1% of total hemoglobin. Central cyanosis usually occurs when methemoglobin concentration >15%. Normal levels of methemoglobin should be achieved within 20-60 minutes after administration of methylene blue.

Physiologically Iron in Hb is Fe2+

If iron in Hb is Fe3+ → Methemoglobin

questions.text: When a 70-year-old man swallows, he experiences left-sided earache and pain. He has ulcers on the back of his tongue and a non-tender cervical lump that may be palpated. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Oropharyngeal carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis here.

Acute mastoiditis may have ear pain but does not have discomfort when swallowing anddoes not present with an ulcer at the back of tongue.

Herpes zoster infection has a different presentation where patients complain of burning,itching or paraesthesia in one dermatome. Although in Ramsay Hunt Syndrome thepresenting feature is often pain deep within the ear, there is usually a rash or herpeticblisters in the distribution of the nervus intermedius.

A dental abscess would present with worsening pain which may radiate to the ipsilateralear, jaw and neck with a bad taste in the mouth, fever, malaise and trismus (inability toopen the mouth). The ulceration of the tongue does not fit in this case.

Oropharyngeal carcinoma

Features

  • Typical old patient, smoker
  • Persistent sore throat
  • A lump in the mouth or throat
  • Referred otalgia
  • Difficulty swallowing or moving your mouth and jaw
  • Unexplained weight loss

questions.text: On a regular blood test on a day ward, a 60-year-old man who takes spironolactone and ramipril for hypertension was discovered to have increased potassium of 5.8 mmol/L. He is otherwise healthy and does not have any allergies. An ECG is taken, which is completely normal. In light of his potassium levels, what is the ONE BEST FIRST TREATMENT?
questions.solution:
Spironolactone is a potassium sparing diuretics and remipril is an ACEi. Both can cause hyperkalemia.

There are different severities of hyperkalemia, and these are as follows:

  • Mild – 5.5-5.9 mmol/L
  • Moderate – 6.0-6.4 mmol/L
  • Severe: >6.2 mmol/L

The aggression of treatment depends upon the level of potassium, the rate of rise of potassium and any ECG abnormalities seen.

Remember the following in regards to ECG changes in hyperkalemia

  • ECG may be normal even in severe hyperkalemia
  • The absence of ECG changes does not mean there is no need for treatment
  • The presence of ECG changes means a need for urgent treatment
  • The severity of ECG changes does not always relate to the severity of hyperkalemia

Take note of how the question is phrased. It says the best INITIAL treatment.

The best initial treatment is to discontinue the drugs that are directly contributing toward this patient’s hyperkalemia. As we can see, the potassium level in this patient is only slightly elevated so stopping the medication would suffice. We can expect potassium levels to fall. It is important to check for symptoms and do an ECG, but at this level it is unlikely that patient is symptomatic or an ECG is abnormal.

In this question, the patient has a normal ECG with no symptoms so calcium gluconate is not indicated. This man is certainly not a candidate for dialysis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with pain and restriction of movement in his right hip joint for the last 5 months. He has been taking analgesic but has not got any relief from this pain.X-ray of his right hip joint and pelvis reveals thickening of outer cortex of his left proximal femur with mild bowing.Technetium bone scan shows anincreased uptake in the frontal bone, left scapula, left ischium, and whole of his left proximal femur.A basic metabolic profile, including calcium and creatinine levels, is unremarkable.What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
PAGET'S DISEASE

(Osteitis deformans)


This is a condition characterised by a progressive tendency for one or more bones to bend, get thickened and spongy. Tibia is the bone affected most commonly. The cause is not known, but it is understood to be a defect in the osteoclast functions, so that irregular bone resorption and increased bone turnover occurs. The bone is soft and vascular in the initial stages, but becomes dense and hard later. The disease begins after 40 years of age. Presenting complaints are dull pain, and bowing and thickening of the affected bone. X-rays show multiple confluent lytic areas with interspread new bone formation. Bone scan shows an increased uptake. Serum alkaline phosphatase is elevated. Usual complications are pathological fracture and malignant change. Treatment is by calcitonin or diphosphonate.

questions.text: A 41-year-old pregnant lady comes to Emergency department with right upper quadrant pain that has been intensifying for the past 12 hours. For the past two days, she has had dark urine and pale stools. On inspection, her sclera is found to be yellow. Her blood pressure is 145/95 millimetres of mercury. What is the ONE inquiry that is the MOST APPROPRIATE?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic gallstone disease is the second most common abdominal emergency inpregnant women. Pregnancy alters bile composition and gallbladder emptying slows inthe second trimester, increasing the risk of gallstones.

Do not be misled into thinking this is pre-eclampsia due to the high blood pressureand RUQ pain. Blood pressure will be raised in any patient who is in pain. Furthermore,preeclampsia does not present with symptoms of jaundice.

Ultrasound of abdomen is the best option here as an ultrasound will most likely showthe cause which is likely gallstones in this stem.

Raised urinary bilirubin with absent or reduced urobilinogen is suggestive of obstructivejaundice and will merely confirm an obstructive jaundice picture.

questions.text: Over the last 24 hours, an 18-year-old guy has had several episodes of apparent haematuria. There has been no prior history of stomach or loin pain. These symptoms usually appear within a day or two of the onset of an upper respiratory tract infection. Dipstick urine testing reveals albumin and blood. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease)

Features

  • Young male, recurrent episodes of macroscopic haematuria
  • Typically usually with an upper respiratory tract infection or, less often, gastroenteritis. Most patients have a history of an upper respiratory tract infection and, either at the onset or within the first 24-48 hours, there is gross haematuria that lasts for less than three days. The urine is red or brown and there may also be loin pain.
  • Alternatively, there may be no symptoms but urine shows erythrocytes, casts and proteinuria
  • It is associated with a number of other diseases, including Henoch-Schönlein purpura.
  • Of those that do not remit, there is a slow progression to ESKD.

Differentiating between IgA nephropathy and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

IgA Nephropathy Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Develops 1-2 days after URTI
  • Main symptom – Haematuria
  • Young males
  • Develops 1-2 weeks after URTI
  • Main symptom – Proteinuria
  • Associated with a low complement levels

questions.text: A 5 year old boy is diagnosed with cerebral palsy. He has increased tone and deep tendon reflexes in both lower limbs. On CT Head, periventricular leukomalacia is noted. What is the type of cerebral palsy present in this child?
questions.solution:
CEREBRAL PALSY

Cerebral palsy (CP) is defined as a non-progressive neuromotor disorder of cerebral origin. It includes heterogeneous clinical states of variable etiology and severity ranging from minor incapacitation to total handicap. Most of the cases have multiple neurological deficits and variable mental handicap. The term does not include progressive, degenerative or metabolic disorders of the nervous system.

Spastic Cerebral Palsy

This is the commonest form (65%) and is topographically classified into spastic quadriparesis, diplegia or hemi-paresis. Early diagnostic features of neural damage include abnormally persistent neonatal reflexes, feeding difficulties, persistent cortical thumb after 3 months age and a firm grasp. On vertical suspension, the infant goes into scissoring due to adductor spasm with an extensor posture and does not flex his knees or thigh. The stretch tendon reflexes are always brisk. They have variable degrees of mental and visual handicaps, seizures and behavioral problems.

Spastic quadriparesis is more common in term babies and exhibits signs including opisthotonic posture, pseudo-bulbar palsy, feeding difficulties, restricted voluntary movements and motor deficits.

Spastic diplegia is commoner in preterm babies and is associated with periventricular leukomalacia. The lower limbs are more severely affected with extension and adduction posturing, brisk tendon jerks and contractures.

Spastic hemiplegia is usually recognized after 4-6 months age. Early hand preference, abnormal persistent fisting, abnormal posture or gait disturbance may be the presenting complaint. Vascular insults, porencephaly or cerebral anomalies may be associated.

A thorough screen for associated handicaps and developmental assessment is warranted.

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image ?
questions.solution:
ARCUS SENILIS

  • Bilateral white-yellow lipid deposition in the peripheral corneal stroma
  • Begins inferiorly, then superiorly and then later progresses nasally and temporally
  • More dense in the anterior and posterior stroma
  • Clear zone between the arcus and the limbus
  • Seen in 60% men between 40-60 years and almost all men more than 80 years age.
  • Cause
    • Age related degeneration
    • Lipid abnormality - hyperlipoproteinemia, hypercholesterolemia - usually seen in younger patients
  • Unilateral arcus senilis is associated with with carotid artery disease with absence of the arcus on the side of the carotid artery disease

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presented to Pediatric OPD with a bump on her eyelid. Her mother reported that it started as a small lesion that has been progressively increasing in size over several weeks. On examination, a lipogranulomatous inflammation was noted. Your probable diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
Chalazion

  • Lipogranulomatous inflammation.
  • In case of recurrent chalazion or seborrheic blepharoconjunctivitis rule out any sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • Incision and curettage is done from conjunctival side.
  • Horizontal incisions are avoided to minimize damage to meibomian ducts.

Tuberculosis, Fungal and viral agents cause infection and associated inflammation but not lipogranulomatous inflammation

questions.text: A 22 year old man presents to ENT OPD complaining of itching, earache and discharge from the ear. Discharge is watery in consistency and have musty odour. On examination, doctor found black headed filamentous growth which resembled wet blotting paper. Which of the following is likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Patient is suffering from otomycosis due to Aspergillus niger.

Otomycosis

  • Fungal infection of the external auditory canal

C/F:

  • Intense itching
  • Pain in the ear (More with Aspergillus flavus)
  • Watery discharge with a musty odour
  • The fungal mass have wet blotting paper/newspaper appearance
Causes → Aspergillus niger Aspergillus fumigatus Candida
Appearance → Black headedfilamentous growth Greenor brown colour growth White & creamy deposit

Treatment:

  • Syringing, suctioning or mopping.
  • Antifungals: Clotrimazole and povidine iodine

questions.text: A 30-year-old guy arrives with dysphagia that is slowly progressing. Due to retrosternal discomfort, he has been using H2blockers for the past year. He hasn't observed any changes in his weight. A month ago, a haemoglobin level of 13.3g/dL was determined. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Peptic strictures have an association with gastro-oesophageal reflux disease and cancause dysphagia.

The fact that there is no weight loss and haemoglobin is normal points towards abenign cause. Esophageal cancer at this age group is also uncommon.

questions.text: Identify the instrument and for what purpose it is used?

choices.text: Needle holder used for holding needles at junction of anterior 2/3rd and posterior 1/3rd
Babcock’s forceps used for holding lymph nodes
Kocher’s artery forceps used for clamping the arteries.

questions.solution:
Given image is of needle holding used for holding needles at junction of anterior 2/3rd and posterior 1/3rd.

Option b- Babcock’s forceps

This instrument is used for holding round structures like lymph nodes.

Option c- Spencer’s well – It is used for hemostasis.

Option d- Kocher’s artery forceps.

Used for hemostasis by holding bleeding arteries.

questions.text: A 28 year old male who is a case of acute intestinal obstruction posted for laparatomy under general anesthesia with rapid sequence induction.The endotracheal tube for intubation in this patient should not have-

choices.text: Lateral pressure exerted by the cuff <30 cm water
Cuff which provides an airtight seal and facilitate controlled ventilation

questions.solution:
Cuff has no role in fixation of the tube.

The cuff is inflated to seal the airway to deliver mechanical ventilation. A cuff pressure between 20 and 30 cm H2O or 15-22 mm Hg is recommended to provide an adequate seal and reduce the risk of complications. The objective is to maintain the ETT cuff pressure within a range of 20 to 30 cm H2O to prevent tracheal mucosal injury.

In clinical practice,uncuffed tracheal tubes are preferred in children for the fear that the cuff would make airway mucosal injury, tissue edema and fibrosis, leading a life-threatening result.Cuffed tracheal tubes emerge for its unique role in avoiding air leakage and safety in use during intubation.

Uncuffed tube with an internal diameter of 3.5 mm - for infants up to 1 year of age

Cuffed endotracheal tube with an internal diameter of 3.0 mm - may be used for infants more than 3.5 kg and <1 year.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents to Emergency with substernal severe chest pain. The sufferer claims that inspiration makes the pain much worse. His past medical history is unremarkable, but he smokes 20 cigarettes per day and consumes 50 units of alcohol each week. On examination, his chest was found to be clinically clear, and his abdomen was confirmed to be normal. His vitals are noted as:
Temperature 38 C
Respiratory rate 18 breaths/minute
Blood pressure 110/70 mmHg
Oxygen saturation 97%
What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This is simply a diagnosis of exclusion. In pericarditis, the chest pain felt by patients is pleuritic in nature and aggravated by inspiration, coughing and a change to the upright position. The pain is relieved when the patient lies down – an important feature which was deliberately left out of the stem.

The diagnosis of pericarditis involves the typical chest pain, pericardial friction rub on auscultation and/or characteristic ECG changes which this question stem only gives one part of a clue for diagnosis which is the pleuritic chest pain and a fever.

Acute pericarditis

Features

  • Chest pain is described as sharp, stabbing, central chest pain, with radiation to the shoulders and upper arm
  • Chest pain may be pleuritic and is often relieved by sitting forwards
  • Chest pain may be made orse by inspiration, cough, swallowing or movement of the trunk
  • Other symptoms include non-productive cough and dyspnoea
  • Pericardial friction rub on auscultation (clinically, the presence of a pericardial friction rub is pathagnomic – often a rub can be heard even when a pericardial effusion is present).

Causes

  • Viral infections (coxasackie)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Uraemia (causes ‘fibrinous’ pericarditis)
  • Trauma
  • Post-myocardial infarction, Dressler’s syndrome
  • Connective tissue disease

Post myocardial infarction is an extremely important cause to remember for the exam.

ECG changes

  • Widespread ‘saddle-shaped’ ST elevation (Saddle-shaped meaning concavity directed upwards)
  • PR segment depression

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes in for a routine examination. He has enhanced skin pigmentation, spider angioma, and a heart murmur, among other things. He suffers from slight joint pain, notably in his hands. He rarely consumes alcoholic beverages. His liver is firm and has a 10 cm spread on inspection. He was diagnosed with restrictive cardiomyopathy after additional analysis of the heart murmur. What is the ONE THING that he is most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Hepatoma (more often called hepatocellular carcinoma) is a primary malignancy of theliver. The given scenario has features of haemochromatosis of which is among the causes of restrictive cardiomyopathy. It is a very well known fact that. patients with haemochromatosis have an increased risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.

The liver is a primary storage area for iron and will naturally accumulate excess iron.Over time the liver is likely to be damaged by iron overload causing cirrhosis. Cirrhosis and haemochromatosis together will increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

HAEMOCHROMATOSIS

  • Hereditary haemochromatosis (HHC) is an autosomal recessive genetic disease in whichincreased intestinal absorption of iron causes accumulation in tissues, especially theliver, which may lead to organ damage. Other organs that may be affected by irondeposits include the pancreas, joints, heart, skin and gonads.

Presentation

  • Early diagnosis is difficult because HHC is often asymptomatic until the late stages of disease.
  • Symptoms usually start between ages 40-60
  • Initial symptoms are usually vague and nonspecific - eg, fatigue, weakness andheart problems
  • HHC may be diagnosed incidentally - eg, following abnormal serum ferritin or LFTs
  • Symptoms of advanced disease include:
    • Diabetes
    • Bronzing of the skin
    • Hepatomegaly
    • Cirrhosis
    • Arthropathy
    • Cardiac disease - arrhythmias or cardiomyopathy
    • Neurological or psychiatric symptoms - impaired memory, moodswings, irritability, depression

Remember the triad of diabetes, hepatomegaly and bronze pigmentation. This is seen in30% of patients with haemochromatosis

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the clinic with muscle weakness. His physical weakness began in his legs, but it has now spread to his arms. He has lost tendon reflexes and has diminished muscle strength, according to the assessment. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY MECHANISM for this weakness?

choices.text: Reduction in the number of nicotinic acetylcholine at the postsynaptic muscle membrane
Autoimmune degeneration of myelin sheets of peripheral neurons

questions.solution:
You should suspect Gullian – Barre syndrome in ascending symptoms of paresthesia in line with the recent gastroenteritis. The pathophysiology is complicated but you would need to remember that it is an acute inflammatory demyelinating neuropathy.

Guillain – Barre Syndrome

  • Guillain- Barre syndrome is a disorder causing demyelination characterised by weakness, paresthesia and hyporeflexia. Around two-thirds precedes an infction, usually respiratory or gastrointestinal tract. This association with preceding infection suggests that antibodies to the infectious organism also attack antigens in peripheral nerve tissue.

In the stem, there would usually be a history of gastrointestinal or respiratory infection from anywhere between a few days to 3 weeks prior to the onset of weakness.

Presentation:

  • Weakness
    • Presents with an ascending pattern of progressive symmetrical weakness, starting in the lower extremities
    • Reaches a level of maximum severity two weeks after initial onset of symptoms
    • Facial weakness, dysphasia or dysarthria
    • In severe cases, muscle weakness may lead to respiratory failure.
  • Pain
    • Reduced or absent
  • Sensory
    • Paresthesia and sensory loss, starting in the lower extremities.

questions.text: A 24 months old child has a history of multiple infections and multiple episodes of hypocalcemic seizures. What is the likely genetic disorder in this child?
questions.solution:
Digeorge syndrome:

  • Micro deletion of CHR 22q11

  • Short Philtrum
  • Mandibula Hypoplasia
  • Dysmorphism
  • Hypotelorism with antimongoloid slant
  • Prominent bridge of nose

CATCH 22

C – Cardiac anomaly
A – Abnormal face
T – Thymic hypoplasia
H – Hypocalcemia
22 – Chr 22q11 microdeletion

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman claims she has been falling to the ground without warning. She stays awake and remembers everything that happens to her. After the collapse, there is no more confusion. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Drop attacks are sudden spontaneous falls while standing or walking, with complete recovery in seconds or minutes. There is usually no loss of consciousness, and the event is remembered.

The remaining options given usually have a prodrome or identifiable symptoms prior to the episodes like dizziness or pallor. Drop attacks do not have these.

Drop attacks

  • Drop attacks refers to unexplained falls with no prodrome, no loss of consciousness, and rapid recovery. The proportion of falls due to ‘drop attack’ increases with age.

Causes

  • Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
  • Weak legs (eg cauda equine syndrome)

Note that the usual cause is sudden weakness of the legs that causes the patient, usually an older woman, to fall to the ground. There is no warning, no loss of consciousness and no confusion afterwards. The condition is usually benign, resolving spontaneously after a number of attacks.

questions.text: A 60-year-old guy is experiencing pain in his right upper quadrant. In the previous four months, he has lost ten kilogrammes. A palpable liver with nodularities was discovered during the evaluation. He had a right hemicolectomy three years ago for colorectal cancer. What is the MOST APPROPRIATE tumour marker to look into?
questions.solution:
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is especially important to monitor response to treatment and identify relapse in tumours showing raised CEA at diagnosis (e.g.colorectal cancers)

The history of the right upper quadrant discomfort and the examinations of a palpable liver are descriptions of tumour metastasis to the liver. CEA raises with a metastatic tumours from colon whereas alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is elevated in primary hepatocellular carcinoma. So do not get confused and pick AFP where there is a clear history of colorectal carcinoma

Common tumour markers

  • CA 125: Ovarian cancer
  • CA 19-9 :Pancreatic cancer
  • CA 15-3: Breast cancer
  • Prostate specific antigen (PSA): Prostatic carcinoma
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) :Colorectal cancer
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): Hepatocellular carcinoma, teratoma

questions.text: Which of the following is a drug of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis?
questions.solution:
Dermatitis Herpetiformis/ Duhring's Disease

  • It occurs due to gluten hypersensitivity & is strongly associated with celiac disease.
  • Other associations:
    • HLA DQ2, HLA B8 JIPMER 18
    • Anti endomycial antibodies
    • Anti-transglutaminase antibodies
    • (Transglutaminase -3 / epidermal transglutaminase)
  • C/F:
    • extremely pruritic vesicopapules over extensors (Elbow, knee, back buttock)
    • Excoriated lesions over extensors
  • Investigation
    1. Histology-papillary Tip micro abscess (Small collection of neutrophils in the tip of dermal papillae)
    2. DIF:granular Q lgA deposits in dermal papillae.
  • Treatment:
    • TOC- gluten free diet
    • DOC 1-2 mg/kg/body weight Dapsone

questions.text: After a massive haematemesis, a 40-year-old male alcoholic appears. On his chest, he has some more spider naevi. His blood pressure is 100/76 millimetres of mercury, and his pulse rate is 110 beats per minute. A large abdomen with fluctuating dullness is visible on examination. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Spider naevi and ascites are suggestive of liver disease. It is likely that with the historyof alcohol, and his signs and symptoms, he has a diagnosis of chronic liver diseasewhich has resulted in portal hypertension and bleeding from oesophageal varices.

Oesophageal varices

  • Dilated sub-mucosal veins in the lower third of the oesophagus. This can lead to variceal haemorrhage which occurs from the dilated veins (varices) atthe junction between the portal and systemic venous systems. The bleeding is oftensevere and life-threatening. Majority of the patients would have a history of chronicliver disease.

Presentation:

  • Haematemesis (most commonly), melaena
  • Signs of chronic liver disease

Investigation:

  • Endoscopy at early stage

Acute management of variceal bleeding

  • Always start with ABC
  • Correct clotting: FFP, vitamin K
  • Vasoactive agents like terlipressin → Terlipressin should be offered to patientswith suspected variceal bleeding at presentation
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis → reduces mortality in patients with acute upper GIbleeding in association with chronic liver disease
  • Endoscopic variceal band ligation → If band ligation not available, useemergency sclerotherapy as first line
  • Sengstaken-Blakemore tube if uncontrolled haemorrhage
  • Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt (TIPSS) if still unable to control bleeding

Prophylaxis of variceal haemorrhage

  • Propranolol often given at discharge to reduce portal pressure in order to decrease the risk of repeat bleeding

questions.text: 50 years old man came with complaint of fever and pain in abdomen for past one week. Ultrasound of abdomen was performed which revealed a hypoechoic lesion in liver. CECT was done to characterize the lesion [image given below]. Which of the following statement is false regarding the lesion?

choices.text: Most commonly caused by E.coli bacterial infection
Right lobe of liver is the most common site.
Hematogeneous route is the most common source of infection.

questions.solution:
CT image shows a multilocular cystic mass in the posterior segment of the right hepatic lobe abutting the right hemidiaphragm. Note the layered wall (“double target sign”) seen in pyogenic abscess.

Pyogenic abscess can be divided into six categories based on the route of hepatic infection. These include:

  1. biliary source (60%) (Most common) (Multiple abscesses are common)
  2. portal vein seeding (7%)(2nd most common)
  3. direct extension (3%);
  4. hepatic artery seeding (10%) (usually monomicrobial)
  5. cryptogenic (17%);
  6. penetrating trauma (5%).

Organisms:

Solitary abscesses are more likely to be polymicrobial than multiple abscesses.

E.coli → Most common in western countries

Klebsiella pneumoniae → Most common in Asian countries

Staphylococcus → Most common in children particularly suffering from Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

50% of solitary liver abscesses occur in the right lobe of the liver (a more significant part with more blood supply), less commonly in the left liver lobe or caudate lobe.

questions.text: 5 days ago, a 46-year-old woman underwent a thorough abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy. She is now experiencing significant stomach discomfort and bloating. She was advised to drink plenty of water, but she is still unable to pass gas. There are no bowel sounds heard. What is the ONE MOST SUITABLE NEXT STEP?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis here is paralytic ileus and an x-ray can help with diagnosis.

Prolonged surgery is one of the major causes of paralytic ileus and it occurs due to over handling of the bowel.

Paralytic ileus is to be expected in the first few days after abdominal surgery. Bowel sounds are absent and there is no passage of gas. There may be mild distension, but there is usually minimal pain.

PARALYTIC ILEUS

Clinical features

  • Abdominal distension, tympanic or dull on percussion.
  • Abdominal X-ray → Shows air/fluid-filled loops of small and/or large bowel
  • Intestinal ileus usually settles with appropriate treatment.

Treatment

  • Pass an NGT to empty the stomach of fluid and gas if the patient is nauseated or vomiting. Small volumes of tolerated oral intake may help mild ileus to resolve.
  • Ensure adequate hydration by IV infusion (‘drip and suck’).
  • Reduce opiate analgesia and encourage the patient to mobilize.

questions.text: His parents took their 14-year-old son to the hospital because of a painful swelling in his neck. Physical examination indicated a swelling in the midline of his neck, immediately in front of the trachea, below the hyoid bone. It was also discovered that the mass is a palpable, non-tender, fluid-filled lump that travels upwards when swallowed and when the tongue protrudes. Its diameter was estimated to be around 1.5 cm. The patient was suspected of having a thyroglossal cyst after a comprehensive history and physical examination. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE Investigation TO CONDUCT?
questions.solution:
• A thyroglossal cyst is a fibroid cyst that forms from a persistent thyroglossal duct. It usually presents as an asymptomatic fluid-filled midline neck mass below the level of the hyoid bone. It is benign and results from an incomplete closure of the thyroid’s migration path during fetal development.
  • It typically presents as a painless anterior midline neck mass and is found most often in childhood or adolescence. This is a very important point to remember. Thyroglossal cyst accounts for around 75% of midline masses in children.
  • Thyroglossal cysts are congenital, however, the diagnosis can be made at any age with most of them diagnosed before 10 years of age

How do you diagnose a thyroglossal cyst?

  • Ultrasound of the cyst is a sensible next step and is performed to distinguish a solid cyst from fluid-filled components and to visualize the degree of the mass as well as its surrounding tissues. It is the first line imaging study and ultrasound alone can be sufficient to conform the diagnosis in majority of cases.
  • MRI or CT are used when malignancy is suspected but are not used routinely unless there is a large cyst.
  • Thyroid scan with technitium 99m(Tc-99m) can be used to determine if there are any ectopic thyroid tissue. Remember, the wall of a thyroglossal duct cyst is the second most common site for ectopic thyroid tissue. Fine needle aspiration cytology is performed in order to establish the character of the cells inside the cyst. However, given the low incidence of carcinoma in thyroid cyst especially in children, preoperative biopsy of thyroglossal cyst is not cost effective and is not recommended.
  • Diagnostic steps always move from least invasive to most invasive. In majority of questions, the most appropriate investigation would be the gold standard diagnostic step which normally involves a biopsy. This is not the case for thyroglossal cyst. Ultrasound still remains the most appropriate investigation here.

questions.text: A 38yrs old female Pushpa presents with ear discharge, itch and severe pain since last 4 days. She gives history of using Cotton buds to clean ear wax 4 days back. Following image shows an oedematous narrow ear canal obscuring the Tympanic membrane. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
This is a classic case of Otitis externa post self-trauma to ear.

Diffuse Otitis Externa

  • It is also known as swimmer’s ear, tropical ear, telephonist ear.
  • Commonly seen after minor trauma to EAC skin like buds/ itching the ear.
  • Most common organisms are Pseudomonas, E. coli, Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Occurs in immunocompetent individuals.
  • Burning sensation, ear pain, purulent discharge, itching, conductive deafness
  • Treatment: Aural toilet, Ichthammol Glycerine wick and analgesics.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with fever since 6 days and rash on his trunk. On further examination bilateral, non-exudative conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue and cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. What is the most important next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Fever for > 5 days with any 4 out of 5 ‘CREAM’ features
  • Mnemonic → ‘CREAM’
    C B/L non-purulent COnjuctivitis
    R Rash involving trunk
    E Erythema & Edema of Palms & Soles
    A Adenopathy
    M Mucosal involvement (Strawberry Tongue)
  • No diagnostic test
  • Leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, increased ESR or CRP
  • Coronary Artery Aneurysm (Giant > 8 mm in diameter) is an important complication.
  • Scarlet fever is a close D/D of Kawasaki disease

Treatment

  • IV Ig-as soon as diagnosis is made to prevent complication
  • Aspirin-High dose followed by low dose
  • Steroids if persistent fever despite IvIg.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct regarding functions of utricle and saccule?

choices.text: Saccule helps in detecting horizontal linear acceleration
Utricle helps in detecting vertical linear acceleration
Calcium carbonate crystals which cause BPPV are normally present in posterior semi-circular canal

questions.solution:
Utricle and saccule:

  • Detects Linear acceleration
  • Macula – sensory epithelium of utricle and saccule
    • ? Consist of hair cells
    • $ Otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals)

Vestibular part

3 semicircular canals & 2 Sacs

  • Utricle
  • Saccule/sacculus

Semicircular canals

  • Posterior/vertical
  • Lateral/Horizontal
  • Superior/Anterior

questions.text: A 11-year-old child is clinically obese and ranks last in his class in height. His medical background includes a two-year-old renal transplant. Purple striae can be seen on his skin. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Cushing’s syndrome is the most likely diagnosis here. The history of a renal transplant means that he is probably taking exogenous steroids which are causing his syndrome.

The most common presentation of Cushing syndrome is Obesity or Weight gain.

Clinical features Frequency
Weight gain 80%
Moon facies 75%
Purplish skin striae 65%
Hypokalemic alkalosis 15%

questions.text: A 34week gestation female (age 30) presented with history of painless bleed per vagina. JR on duty ordered APT (alkaline denaturation test). How do we interpret this test?

choices.text: It is quantitative test used to determine site of bleed (maternal or fetal)
Maternal RBCs doesn’t denature in alkaline medium and stays red.
Fetal blood stays red as it can withstand alkaline medium.
Fetal RBCs are more prone to alkaline medium than maternal RBCs.

questions.solution:
APT test –

Addition of NAOH to vaginal bleed in a test tube causes denaturation of RBCs.

Maternal blood gets denatured and becomes colorless but fetal blood is resistant to alkaline medium.

It is a qualitative test used to distinguish between maternal and fetal blood.

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient who was on estrogen containing pills presents with sudden painless loss of vision. The fundus image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Given image is showing mild venous congestion , tortuosity, and multiple dot-blot, superficial flame shaped hemorrhage suggestive of non ischemic type of CRVO.

Predisposing factors :

  • DM
  • Hypertension
  • Arteriosclerosis
  • Hypercoagulability
  • OCP users
  • Hyperviscosity of blood

questions.text: A 30y/o female was diagnosed with eclampsia and is being treated with MgSo4. What is the loading dose of this drug according to Pritchard’s regimen?

choices.text: 4gm (20%) IV followed by 5gm (50%) IM in each buttock
4gm (50%) IV followed by 5gm (20%) IM in each buttock
5gm (20%) IV followed by 4gm (50%) IM in each buttock
5gm (50%) IV followed by 4gm (20%) IM in each buttock

questions.solution:
Pritchard’s regimen for eclampsia

MgSO4 is the drug of choice for eclampsia.

  • Pritchard’s Regimen
    • IV MgSo4 4 gms
    • IM MgSo4 10 gms (5mgs in each buttock)
    • IV MgSo4 2 gms added if no relief
  • Follow up with
    • IM MgSo4 for 24 hrs after the last convulsion or the delivery whichever is later.
    • Monitor Knee jerks ? +
      Respiratory ? >1 4 min
      Urine output ? > 100 ml/4 hrs

questions.text: A 30 years-old female presents with headache and transient obscurations of her vision. On examination, no focal neurological deficit was seen. Which one of the following would you start her on?
questions.solution:
• The above image shows a partial empty sella which is seen in raised intracranial tension.
  • The pseudotumor cerebri syndrome (PTCS) is a perplexing syndrome of increased intracranial pressure without a space-occupying lesion. annual incidence of pseudotumor cerebri syndrome.
  • Symptoms include headache, transient visual obscurations, pulsatile tinnitus, visual loss, diplopia. Signs include 6th nerve palsy and papilledema.

Figure: Flattening of the posterior sclera and protrusions of the optic nerve heads(This is the radiographic correlate with papilledema)

  • In addition, for the diagnosis to be made brain imaging must show no structural causes of raised ICP, and lumbar puncture CSF opening pressure >25 cm H2O in relaxed adults and >28 cm H2O in a (sedated) child with normal CSF analysis.
  • In the absence of papilledema or 6th nerve palsy, a possible diagnosis of PTCS is suggested by MRI showing at least three of:
    • empty sella,
    • flattening of the posterior aspect of the globe,
    • distension of perioptic subarachnoid space (¼/- tortuous optic nerve),
    • transverse venous sinus stenosis.
  • The main goal of treatment is the preservation of vision.
  • As such, patients presenting with deteriorating vision require more aggressive initial management.
  • General management strategies include weight loss (including bariatric surgery in some cases), salt restriction.
  • Treatment options include acetazolamide, topiramate (headache and causes weight loss), ventriculoperitoneal or lumboperitoneal CSF shunting, optic nerve sheath fenestration, and in some cases venous sinus stenting.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman appears with bloody diarrhoea, tiredness, and weight loss for the past four months. She has stomach pains and passes stools more than eight times every day. Deep ulcers and skip lesions were seen during an endoscopy. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of Crohn’s disease is quite clear here. Lethargy and weight loss are non specific signs that can occur in Crohn’s disease. The give away here is the deep ulcers, and skip lesions that is seen on endoscopy which is pathognomic for Crohn’s disease.

Note that although Crohn’s disease usually has non bloody diarrhoea, it occasionally may present with bloody diarrhoea.

Crohn’s disease

  • Chronic transmural inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract
  • Can involve any part from mouth to anus but most commonly affects the small intestine and colon
  • Most common primary surgical disease of the small bowel
  • Occurs in the second and third decades of life

Pathology

  • Disease process is discontinuous and segmental
  • Rectal sparing - characteristic of Crohn’s
  • Perirectal and perianal involvement- occurs in one third of patients
  • Areas of diseased bowel separated by areas of grossly appearing normal bowel called skip areas are seen
  • Striking finding - extensive fat wrapping causes by the circumferential growth of the mesenteric fat around the bowel wall
  • The bowel wall progressively becomes increasingly thickened, firm, rubbery and almost incompressible
  • The uninvolved proximal bowel - dilated due to obstruction of the diseased segment
  • Earliest gross pathologic lesion - superficial aphthous ulcer noted in the mucosa
  • Ulcers are characteristically linear and coalesce to produce transverse sinuses with islands of normal mucosa in between - cobblestone appearance
  • Characteristic histologic lesions- noncaseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells

Clinical features

  • Symptomatic periods of abdominal pain and diarrhea interspersed with asymptomatic period
  • Most common clinical manifestations - abdominal pain> diarrhoea and weight loss
  • Most common symptom- intermittent and colicky abdominal pain most common in the lower abdomen
  • Crohn’s disease can be classified by Vienna classification on the basis of age at onset, behaviour and site of origin

Diagnosis

  • Barium contrast studies
    • Cobblestone appearance of the mucosa composed of linear ulcers, transverse sinuses amd clefts
    • Kantor sign - long lengths of narrowed terminal ileum
    • Rose thorn appearance due to deep fissuring ulcers
  • Serological markers
  • Perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody
  • Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody (ASCA) → differentiates Crohn’s from ulcerative colitis
  • Outer membrane porin of flagellin ( anti-CBir1)
  • Outer membrane porin of E.coli ( OmpC-IgG)

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman complains of growing dyspnea and breathlessness when she exerts herself. She's been having trouble sleeping recently, and she claims she has to sleep with three pillows at night. The patient had bilateral pedal oedema up to the level of her calf on examination, as well as extensive crepitations bilaterally on auscultation. A pansystolic murmur can be heard at the cardiac apex when the heart is auscultated. An ECG was performed, which revealed a broad P wave. She has no medical issues other than asthma, which she was diagnosed with at the age of seven, and rheumatic fever when she was fourteen. She does not consume alcoholic beverages or smoke.What is the SINGLE most likely cardiac defect that this patient has?
questions.solution:
The patient has mitral regurgitation secondary to rheumatic fever.

Some exam clinchers for mitral regurgitation:

  • Previous disease that affects the mitral valve
  • Signs and symptoms of pulmonary oedema will appear in the stem
  • Panysystolic murmur at the cardiac apex is the murmur of mitral regurgitation
  • Chest x- ray if given may show an enlarged left side of the heart

Mitral regurgitation

Common scenarios in the exam are:

  • History of rheumatic fever
  • A few weeks after a myocardial infarction where patient may be admitted for pulmonary oedema

Clinical features

Left ventricular failure

  • Dyspnoea
  • Orthopnoea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dysponea

With severe and chronic mitral regurgitation, right – sided failure would eventually occur leading to:

  • Oedema
  • Ascites

Important clinical sign – Pansystolic apical murmur radiating to the axilla

ECG – signs of left ventricular hypertrophy and left atrial enlargement (e.g. broad P wave)

Chest x-ray – may show an enlarged left side of the heart

Diagnosis

  • Echocardiography

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct regarding turbinates of the nose?

The superior turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone
The middle turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone
The inferior turbinate is a part of the ethmoid bone
The Inferior turbinate is a separate bone
questions.solution: The superior and middle turbinates are parts of ethmoid bone whereas inferior turbinate is an independent separate bone.

questions.text: On a newborn’s physical examination, small, pearl like nodules are noted on its hard palate, as shown in the following image. What is the best treatment for this finding?
questions.solution:
5 Epstein Pearls:

  • Pearl like white lesions
  • Hard palate involved
  • Epithelial inclusion cysts

Epstein Pearls

The alveolar ridge may have natal teeth or retention cysts (also called Epstein pearls) that disappear in few weeks. No treatment or removal is needed.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman had her colostomy removed four days ago. Her stoma now has a little bulge that fluctuates. Her temperature is 37.9 degrees Celsius, her respiratory rate is 18 beats per minute, and her pulse rate is 80 beats per minute. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE management technique?
questions.solution: Fluctuating small swelling indicates an abscess has formed. Local exploration would be beneficial in this scenario. Stomal abscess is a collection of pus (infection) occurring just under the skin around the site of the stoma. Antibiotics and drainage of the pus is sometimes required.

questions.text: Abdominal pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, unsteadiness, and numbness of the lower limbs plague a 32-year-old lady. These symptoms have been there for a long time. The results of an ECG, chest x-ray, abdomen ultrasound, and neurological assessment were all normal. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Somatization disorder is the experience of bodily symptoms with no physical cause for them, with presumed psychological causation. All investigations would be normal.

Hypochondriasis → is the persistent belief in the presence of an underlying serious DISEASE, e.g. cancer or HIV. The patient again refuses to accept reassurance or negative test results.

Munchausen's syndrome →also known as factitious disorder. Patients intentionally falsify their symptoms and past history and fabricate signs of physical or mental disorder with the primary aim of obtaining medical attention and treatment. The diagnostic features are the intentional and conscious production of signs, falsification, or exaggeration of the history and the lack of gain beyond medical attention and treatment.

Conversion (dissociative) disorders → typically involves loss or disturbance of normal motor or sensory function which initially appears to have a neurological or other physical cause but is later attributed to a psychological cause. The patient does not consciously feign the symptoms or seek material gain. Patients may be indifferent to their apparent disorder.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy weighing 65 kgs presents with pain in the hip and limp. On examination, there is limited abduction and internal rotation of the hip. The most likely clinical diagnosis in this patient is-
questions.solution:
SUPPED CAPITAL FEMORAL EPIPHYSIS

In this condition, the upper femoral epiphysis may get displaced at the growth plate, usually postero-medially, resulting in coxa vara. The slip occurs gradually in majority of cases, but in some it occurs suddenly.

CAUSES

Aetiology is not known but it is thought to be a result of trauma in the presence of some not yet understood underlying abnormality. It occurs more commonly in unduly fat and sexually underdeveloped; or tall, thin sexually normal children.

CLINICAL FEATURES

Following are the salient clinical features:

  • Age: It occurs at puberty (between 12-14 years).
  • Sex: It is commoner in boys.
  • Side: It occurs on both sides in 30 per cent of CAWS.
  • There is a definite history of trauma in some cases.
  • It is commoner in patients with endocrine abnormalities.

Presenting symptoms:

Pain in the groin, often radiating to the thigh and the knee is the common presenting complaint. Often in the initial stages, the symptoms are considered due to a 'sprain', and are disregarded. They soon disappear only to recur. Limp occurs early and is more constant.

Examination:

The leg is found to be externally rotated and 1-2 cm short. Limitation of hip movements is characteristic - there is limited abduction and internal rotation, with a corresponding increase in adduction and external rotation. When the hip is flexed, the knee goes towards the ipsilateral axilla. Muscle bulk may be reduced. Trendelenburg's sign may be positive.

RADIOLOGICAL FEATURES

X-ray changes are best seen on a lateral view of the hip. The following signs may be present:

  • On AP view: The growth plate is displaced towards the metaphyseal side. A line drawn along the superior surface of the neck remains superior to theheadunlike in a normal hip where it passes bisecting the head —Trethowan's sign
  • • On lateral view: The head is angulated on the neck. This can be detected early.

TREATMENT

It is based on the following considerations:

  1. Treatment of an acute slip: This is by closed reduction and pinning, as for a fracture of the neck of the femur.
  2. Treatment of a gradual slip: This depends upon the severity of the slip present. If it is less than 1 /3 the diameter of the femoral neck, the epiphysis is fixed internally in situ. If the slip is more than 1/3, a corrective osteotomy is performed at the inter-trochanteric region.
  3. Treatment of the unaffected side in unilateral cases: Since the incidence of bilateral involvement is 30 per cent, prophylactic pinning of the unaffected side in a case with unilateral slip is justified.

questions.text: Despite having a healthy appetite, a 39-year-old man has lost 7 kg unintentionally in the last two months. Palpitations, sweating, and diarrhoea are all among his complaints. He has a bulge in the front of his neck that moves around when he swallows. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE DISEASE?
questions.solution:
He has signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism. The mass is likely to be a goitre rather than thyroid cancer as thyroid cancers usually do not manifest with symptoms of hyperthyroidism.

HYPERTHYROIDISM CLINICAL FEATURES

Symptoms

  • Hyperactivity, irritability
  • Insomnia
  • Heat intolerance
  • Sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue
  • Weight loss
  • Increased appetite
  • Pruritus
  • Increased stool frequency
  • Oligomenorrhoea or amenorrhoea

Signs

  • Sinus tachycardia, atrial fibrillation
  • Fine tremor

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the clinic with erectile dysfunction and urine incontinence. Ataxia, stiffness, and a pill-rolling tremor of the hands are all visible in him. Postural hypotension is also discovered throughout the test. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Shy – dragger syndrome

  • A rare neurodegenerative disorder, caused by cell loss in certain areas of the brain and the spinal cord, leading to a variety of symptoms characterised by Parkinsonian features, cerebellar ataxia and autonomic dysfunction (particularly urogenital)
  • Mean age at onset is between 50 and 70 years

Presentation:

  • Urinary dysfunction : most common presentation
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Postural hypotension
  • Cerebellar ataxia Parkinsonia symptoms with poor response to levodopa

In the exam, if you get a stem with characteristics of parkinsonism (rigidity, pill rolling tremor of the hands) plus autonomic dysfunction (urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction) consider Shy-drager syndrome syndrome as the answer.

questions.text: Due to marital issues, a couple attends a marriage counselling session. The wife claims that her husband is having affairs, despite the fact that she has no proof. She is "crazy," according to her husband, because she is having him followed by a private detective and is worried with him being unfaithful. She examines his personal possessions on a daily basis for signs of adultery. Her behaviours are placing a lot of strain on their relationship. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY TYPE OF SYNDROME she has?
questions.solution:
Othello Syndrome → is a type of delusional jealousy, marked by suspecting a faithfulpartner of infidelity like cheating, adultery or having an affair. The patient mayattempt monitoring his spouse or partner.

Frégoli delusion → is when a person holds a delusional belief that different peopleare in fact a single person who changes appearance or is in disguise.

Capgras syndrome → A type of delusional misidentification in which the patientbelieves that a person known to them has been replaced by a ‘double’ who is to allexternal appearances identical, but is not the ‘real person’.

Cotard syndrome → is a presentation of psychotic depressive illness characterisedbya combination of severely depressed mood with nihilistic delusions. The patient maystate that he is already dead and should be buried. He may state that his insides havestopped working and are rotting away, or that he has stopped existing altogether.

questions.text: A 45-year-old guy claims he is being sought by the police for a crime he denies committing, but this is inaccurate after further examination. He has trouble concentrating and has a short-term memory problem. For the past 20 years, he has admitted to consuming huge amounts of alcohol. He can carry on a reasonable discussion, but a few moments later he has no recollection of the conversation. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Korsakoff syndrome

  • This termed Wernicke- Korsakoff syndrome and is characterised by the addition of antero – and retrograde amnesia and confabulation in addition to the classic triad of confusion, ataxia and opthalamoplegia found in Wemicke’s encephalopathy.
  • Those with Korsakoff syndrome may “confabulate”, or make up, information they cannot remember. They are not “lying” but may actually believe their invented explanations.
  • They create events to fill the gaps in day – to day memory. For example, a person who has been in hospital for several weeks may talk convincingly about having just visited their aunt earlier that day. This is more common in the early stages of the condition.
  • Individuals may seem able to carry on a coherent conversation, but moments later be unable to recall that the conversation took place or to whom they spoke. They can often answer questions promptly with inaccurate and sometimes bizarre answers.

questions.text: A 50-year-old guy arrives to mergency with unexpected abdominal pain that began about an hour earlier. The pain is now widespread, consistent, and excruciating. On the stretcher, he is inert, diaphoretic, and breathing is shallow and fast. His abdomen is stiff and guarded, and very tender to deep probing. X-rays reveal the presence of open air beneath the diaphragm. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Definitely an acute abdomen. The X-ray which shows free air under the diaphragm isclassical for a perforation. Lying motionless and having a rigid, tender abdomen withsigns of guarding is typical for a perforated peptic ulcer.

  • Perforated peptic ulcer
    • Perforation of a gastric or duodenal ulcer is usually a severely painful sudden event. Itmay occur in those without known peptic ulcer disease, as well as those with previouslydiagnosed problems. However, close questioning may reveal recent symptomsattributed to ‘indigestion’.

Sudden localized epigastric pain spreads to the remainder of the abdomen the pain isworse on coughing or moving and may radiate to the shoulder tip

Examination

  • Although distressed, the patient often prefers to lie still, rather than roll about. Absent bowel sounds, shock, generalized peritonitis and fever develop as time passes.

Investigations

  • An erect chest X-ray will demonstrate free gas under the diaphragm In those cases where the diagnosis is suspected, but not proven by X-ray, a contrast CTscan may help.

Treatment

  • Provide IV analgesia
  • Give an antiemetic (eg IV metoclopramide 10mg).
  • Resuscitate with IV 0.9 % saline.
  • Refer to the surgeon and give IV antibiotics

questions.text: Her husband brings a 55-year-old woman into the Emergency Department after she has become progressively drowsy over the past 48 hours. She had a right mastectomy for breast cancer 5 years ago. He says she's been moaning about being thirsty for the previous week. She is depressed and has been on fluoxetine for four months. What is the MOST LIKELY REASON for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Drowsiness and increased thirst with a history of breast cancer should spark the thought of hypercalcemia as a differential. Breast cancers commonly spread to bones and remember, bone metastases are one of the most common causes of hypercalcemia.

Fluoxetine has no significance in this scenario however depression can be worsened with hypercalcemia.

Aetiology

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism – this is the main cause of hypercalcemia. It is the most common cause of hypercalcemia but it is usually mild most of the time so most patient have no symptoms at all
  • Malignancy – i.e. multiple myeloma, production of PTH like molecule (squamous cell carcinoma of the lung). This is a common cause of hypercalcemia that requires hospital admission
  • Familial hypocalciurichyprcalcaemia
  • Immobilization
  • Sarcoidosis

Clinical features

Mnemonic: “moans, stones, groans, and bones”.

  • Neuro and psych: hypercalcemia results in decreased mental activity leading to lethargy, confusion and depression (Groans)
  • Gastrointestinal: hypercalcemia results in decreased bowel activity such as constipation (Moans)
  • Renal: Hypercalcemia results in polyuria and polydipsia because of the induction of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Calcium also precipitates in the kidney, resulting in both kidney stones as well as nephrolithiasis. (stones).
  • Bone pain is only seen when it is hyperparathyroidism which is causing hypercalcemia (bones)
  • Cardiovascular: The ECG shows a short QT

Hypercalcemia: management

  • The initial management of hypercalcemia is rehydration with normal saline, typically 3-4 litres/day. Increasing the circulating volume with 0.9% saline, helps to increase the urinary output of calcium
  • Following rehydration bisphosphonates may be administered intyravenously.

Other less used options include:

  • Calcitonin – it has fewer side-effects than bisphosphonates but is less effective in reducing hypercalcemia.
  • Steroids in sarcoidosis
  • Cinicalcet hydrochloride is a calcimimetic agent that effectively reduces parathyroid levels in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism
  • Haemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis may be relevant in patients with severe hypercalcemia secondary to renal failure
  • Furosemide has a limited role – it is occasionally used where there is fluid overload but it does not reduce serum calcium

questions.text: A 37y/o female presented with history of amenorrhea for 6 months. Investigations revealed premature ovarian failure. Which of the following is not an indicator of ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Explain premature ovarian failure.

In case of premature ovarian failure number of ovarian follicles decreases significantly due to which there is amenorrhea.

To determine the ovarian reserve following investigations can be done

  • Antral follicular count
  • Follicular stimulating hormone
  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (best method)

questions.text: The mother of a 4-year-old child brings him to the emergency room because he has been vomiting for the past four days. He displays clinical evidence of mild to severe dehydration on examination. What do you think his arterial blood gas profile will reveal?

choices.text: A low pH and low PCO2
A low pH and high PCO2
A high pH and low PCO2
A high pH and high PCO2

questions.solution: Prolonged vomiting causes loss of H+ from the body resulting in metabolic alkalosis. Thus, pH will be higher than usual. To compensate for metabolic alkalosis, the respiratory system will retain carbon dioxide through slower breathing or alveolar hypoventilation in attempts to diminish the change in pH that would otherwise occur. This would result in a higher PCO2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of "patchy hair loss" for the past six weeks. Her other medical problems include hypothyroidism and gastroesophageal reflux disease.Scalp exam reveals several well-demarcated, non scarred, circular areas of complete hair loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hair loss?
questions.solution:
Alopeciaareata

  • it is an autoimmune condition
  • C/F:- Patchy hair (patches of hair loss are present).
  • On examination, these patches show exclamation mark sign (broken hair follicle with broad distal and thin proximal shaft).
  • exclamation marksign:
    • hair follicle tapers downwards (normally hair follicle tapers upwards)
    • seen at the periphery of the patch
    • it is a microscopic finding

questions.text:
A 39-year-old lady has been fatigued and lethargic. Despite taking enalapril, she has a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. Her blood test results are as follows:
Haemoglobin 130 g/L
Serum sodium 144 mmol/L
Serum potassium 3.1 mmol/L
What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Conn’s syndrome (Adrenal adenoma)

Think of conn’s in these contexts:

  • Hypertension associated with hypokalemia
  • Refractory hypertension, e.g. despite > 3 antihypertensive drugs
  • Hypertension occurring before age 40

Classic features include:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia (usually <3.5 mmol/L, although 70% of patients may be normokalaemic)
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Sodium may be normal or at the high end of normal
  • Weakness may be present from hypokalaemia
  • Headaches and lethargy may also be present

Management

  • Medical management is used in the period to surgery. Medical management involves the use of aldosterone antagonists – e.g. spironolactone.
  • Surgery is the definitive treatment. Surgical treatment involves adrenalectomy. Laparoscopic surgery is safe and effective and may be better than open surgery.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman develops a headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, and a fluctuating loss of consciousness over time. On Gram stain, there is lymphocytosis and reduced glucose in the cerebral spinal fluid, but no organism. The CT head was found to be normal. What is the ONE organism that is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Tuberculous meningitis would show lymphocytosis and decreased glucose.

Characteristic cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings in meningitis:

Bacterial meningitis Viral meningitis Tuberculous meningitis
Glucose Low Normal Low
Protein High Normal to high High
White cells Mainly neutrophil Increased lymphocytes Neutrophils in early disease, lymphocytes later

questions.text: An 85-year-old war veteran is complaining of a loss of appetite and claims to have lost weight in recent months. He claims that he passed some blood in his pee, but that he was not in any pain. He says it's tough for him to completely empty his bladder and that he has to urinate more frequently than usual. He also claims that his pelvic pain has been worse in the last three months. PSA is 9.5 ng/ml, according to a recent report. What is the MOST LIKELY CAUSE for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
These are the features of prostate cancer. The raised PSA would be a reason to investigate further for prostate cancer.

The pelvic pain could be a sign of bone metastasis or it could be obstructive symptoms due to prostate cancer.

PROSTATE CARCINOMA

Risk factors

  • Increasing age is the most important risk factor
  • Men of black African-Caribbean family origin
  • First-degree relative with prostate cancer

Presentation

  • Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) do not particularly raise suspicion of prostate cancer because LUTS are common in older men and are rarely the presenting symptom of prostate cancer. However, locally advanced prostate cancer may cause obstructive LUTS

Local disease:

  • Raised PSA on screening
  • Weak stream, hesitancy, sensation of incomplete emptying, urinary frequency, urgency, urge incontinence
  • Urinary tract infection

Locally invasive disease:

  • Haematuria, dysuria, incontinence
  • Haematospermia
  • Perineal and suprapubic pain
  • Obstruction of ureters, causing loin pain, anuria, symptoms of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease

Metastatic disease:

  • Bone pain or sciatica
  • Paraplegia secondary to spinal cord compression
  • Lymph node enlargement
  • Lethargy (anaemia, uraemia)
  • Weight loss

questions.text: After experiencing a seizure, a 63-year-old man presents. He is focused and aware. On examination, hyperreflexia of the arm and inattention on the left side are noted. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Inattention or neglect is a feature of parietal lobe lesion. Seizure may occur in space occupying lesions.

The most likely explanation for this answer is that the cerebral tumour has caused the right parietal lobe of the brain to be affected which can lead to neglect for the left side of the visual field, causing a patient with neglect to behave as if the left side of sensory space is nonexistent (although they can still turn left).

In an extreme case, a patient with neglect might fail to eat the food on the left half of their plate, even though they complain of being hungry. If someone with neglect is asked to draw a clock, their drawing might show only the numbers 12 to 6, or all 12 numbers might be on one half of the clock face with the other half distorted or blank. Neglect patients may also ignore the contralesional side of their body; for instance, they might only shave, or apply makeup to, the nonneglected side. These patients may frequently collide with objects or structures such as door frames on the side being neglected.
