questions.text: A woman presents for contraceptive counselling. She is 32 years old and has no contraindications for use of Oral contraceptive pills. The doctor tells her that the failure rate of these pills is less than 1 per HWY (Hundred Woman Years). This failure rate is calculated as.

choices.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies
Total accidental pregnancies × 100 / Number of women Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy
Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy

questions.solution:
The use-effectiveness of contraceptive method is expressed as Pearl rate & life table technique. Pearl rate or pearl index was introduced by Raymond Pearl in 1932 The rate is expressed as pregnancy rate per 100 women-years (HWY) & calculated as

Pregnancy rate per HWY = Total accidental pregnancies × 1200/ Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive

1200 is the number of months in 100 years

questions.text: A 31-year-old gym instructor who had previously been in good health was engaged in a car accident. He had an intracapsular femur fracture, which necessitated surgery. He undergoes a hemi-arthroplasty and is admitted to the orthopaedic ward. What is the most likely complication that he might face?
questions.solution: The most common post-operative complication is an infection, including wound and lung infections (hospital-acquired pneumonia). The femoral head has been replaced (hemiarthroplasty), therefore tehre is no risk of femoral head avascular necrosis. There is a risk of pulmonary embolism however now with early mobilisation and venousthromboembolism prophylaxis, it is not the most common complication.

questions.text: An indirect inguinal hernia has been detected in a 35-year-old construction worker. Which of the following statements most accurately describes indirect inguinal hernias?

choices.text: Passes through the superficial ring only
Lies above and lateral to the pubic tubercle
Does not pass through the superficial inguinal ring
Passes through the deep inguinal ring

questions.solution:
Indirect inguinal hernias occur when abdominal contents protrude through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels; this may be caused by failure of embryonic closure of the processus vaginalis. An indirect inguinal hernia like other inguinal hernias protrudes through the superficial inguinal ring. It is the most common cause of groin hernia.

In an indirect inguinal hernia, the protrusion passes through the deep inguinal ring and islocated lateral to the inferior epigastric artery.

questions.text: A child of 8 kg was brought by her mother to OPD which on examination had bitot's spots in both eyes. Which of the following is the most appropriate schedule to prescribe vitamin A to this child?

choices.text: 2 lakh units IM on day 0,1 and 14
1 lakh units IM on day 0,1, and 14

questions.solution:
• Children < 1 year of age or weighing <8 kg:1 lakh IU orally on days 0, 1 and 14.
  • Children equal to or >1 year of age or weighing >8 kg:2 lakh IU orally on days 0,1 and 14
  • IM dose is half of the oral dose

questions.text:
Match the following statements regarding theories about pathogenesis of endometriosis.





Sampson’s theory
Meyer and Ivan off theory
Halban theory




Retrograde menstruation
Lymphatic theory
Coelomic metaplasia

choices.text: I – A, II – C, III – B
I – A, II – B, III – C
I – C, II – B, III – A
I – C, II – A, III – B

questions.solution:
Pathogenesis of endometriosis

Halban theory suggests lymphatic spread, Meyer and Ivan off theory explains coelomic metaplasia and Sampson’s theory explains retrograde menstruation.

Sites Theory
  • Pelvic endometriosis
  • Pelvic peritoneum
  • Retrograde menstruation
  • Coelomic metaplasia
  • Abdominal viscera
  • Rectovaginal septum
  • Umbilicus
  • Coelomic metaplasia
  • Abdominal scar
  • Episiotomy scar
  • Vagina, cervix
  • Lymph nodes
  • Distant sites (Lungs, pleura, skin, lymph nodes, nerves)
  • Direct implantation
  • Lymphatic spread
  • Vascular spread
  • Genetic
    Immunologic

questions.text: For the past 6 weeks, a 39-year-old male has had a painful palpable mass at his anus. The discomfort is described as throbbing, and it gets worse when you sit down. The lump is warm, erythematous, and sensitive when examined. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution: This is a very straightforward question. Although many of the options could be very well correct, the history of diabetes should point you towards an infective cause. Hence, perianal abscess is the answer. It is one of the common causes of anorectal pain. Perianal abscesses have a gradual onset, usually with a constant localized perianal pain. Throbbing and severe are good ways to describe a perianal abscess especially if the patient describes the pain as worse when sitting down. Tenderness and swelling is common and occasionally with discharge. Other symptoms also include constipation or pain associated with bowel movements.

questions.text: After being stabbed in the chest with a knife, a 46-year-old man was taken to A&E. His chest is completely clear on both sides. His heart sounds are muffled, and his neck veins appear to be distended. His blood pressure is 84/40 mmHg, and his heart rate is 110 beats per minute. What is the ONE MOST APPROPRIATE EXAMINATION THAT CAN LEAD TO A DISEASE?
questions.solution:
This question clearly points towards cardiac tamponade. His chest is bilaterally clear thus we can therefore exclude pneumothorax or pleural effusion. Muffled heart sound, distended neck veins, hypotension are called Beck’s triad and it is a classical finding in cardiac tamponade. This is diagnosed with an echocardiogram.

Comparing common features of acute pericarditis, pericardial effusion, cardiac tamponade.

These are the most common features that are asked in exams.

Acute pericarditis Pericardial effusion Cardiac Tamponade
Cause

Causes include

  • Viral infections (coxasackie)
  • Tuberculosis
  • Uraemia
  • Trauma
  • Post-myocardial infarction, Dressler’s syndrome
  • Connective tissue disease
 Any cause of pericarditis (see left) Any cause of pericarditis (see left) but especially trauma
Clinical features Central chest pain worse on inspiration or lying flat and relieved by sitting forward Dyspnoea Raised JVP Pulse ­BP ¯Muffled heart sounds ­ JVP Beck’s triad: Falling BP, rising, JVP, muffled heart sounds
Test

ECG classically shows concave (saddle-shaped) ST segment elevation.

Troponin may be raised

CXR shows enlarged, globular heart.

ECG shows low-voltage QRS complexes and alternating

 Echo is diagnostic
Treatment NSAIDS Pericardiocentesis Urgent pericardiocentesis
  • Cardiac Tamponade
    • A life – threatening condition in which a pericardial effusion has developed so rapidly or has become so large that it compresses the heart.

Etiology

  • Usually penetrating or blunt chest trauma

Features

  • Dyspnoea
  • Raised JVP – seen by having neck veins which are distended
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Muffles heart sounds
  • Pulsus paradoxus

Remember – Beck’s triad: Muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, and hypotension

Diagnosis

  • Echocardiography

Treatment

  • Pericardiocentesis
